com.smartsockets
Interface TipcMsg

All Superinterfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, TipcDefs
public interface TipcMsg
extends TipcDefs, java.lang.Cloneable

Provides access to message objects.

Messages can only be created from the TipcSvc factory class with TipcSvc.createMsg(com.smartsockets.TipcMt).

A message consists of a type (TipcMt), properties, and zero or more fields. The field types are used to convert the field data from the format used by the sending platform to the format used by the receiving platform (byte order, etc.). These types are: 

   BINARY - an array of uninterpreted bytes (byte[])
   CHAR   - a character (char)
   STR    - an array of signed bytes representing a string (String)
   INT2   - a signed 2 byte integer (short)
   INT4   - a signed 4 byte integer (int)
   INT8   - a signed 8 byte integer (long)
   REAL4  - a 4 byte real number (float)
   REAL8  - an 8 byte real number (double)
   REAL16 - a 16 byte real number (unsupported by Java)
   MSG    - an embedded SmartSockets message (TipcMsg)
   BOOL   - a boolean value (boolean)
   BYTE   - a single byte (byte)
   UTF8   - an array of bytes representing a UTF-8 encoded string (String)
   XML    - a XML object (TutXml)
   OBJECT - a Java object (Object)

Method Detail

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
Clones the message.

Returns:
A clone of the message.

ack

public void ack()
         throws TipcException
Acknowledges the receipt of a message received by Guaranteed Message Delivery.

Throws:
TipcIOException - if there is a problem sending the acknowledgement
TipcException

destroy

public void destroy()
             throws TipcException
Deprecated. This method is deprecated as of SmartSockets 6.4. Instead use the ack() method.

Destroys the message. If the message was received using GMD, this will also acknowledge the message.

Throws:
TipcIOException - if there is a problem acking a GMD message.
TipcException

appendBinary

public void appendBinary(byte[] binary_data)
Appends a binary field to a message. No conversion will occur for binary fields. It is up to the programmer to provide any required conversion.

Parameters:

Since:
SmartSockets 6.0

appendByte

public void appendByte(byte byte_data)
Appends a byte field to a message.

Parameters:
byte_data - data for new message field
Since:
SmartSockets 6.0

appendObject

public void appendObject(java.lang.Object obj)
                  throws TipcIOException
Appends an arbitrary Java Object to the message. The object will be encoded in a binary field, using the standard serialization mechanism. Therefore, the object passed to this method must implement the Serializable interface. Note that any objects to be serialized must not only themselves be implemented as Serializable, but all of the classes they extend must be Serializable.

This object will only be useful to receiving clients in Java. C/C++ clients will receive a binary field which may be forwarded to other Java clients.

Parameters:
obj - the object to be appended
Throws:
TipcIOException - if the object serialization fails
See Also:
nextObject()

appendUnknown

public void appendUnknown(int field_type)
                   throws TipcException
Appends a new field of the specified type to the message, but marks the field as an 'unknown value'. The constants required for the parameter, field_type, are specified in this clas and can be recognized by their FT_* names.

Parameters:
field_type - the type of field to append and mark as of 'unknown value'
Throws:
TipcAssertionException - if bad field_type parameter passed in
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
getCurrentFieldKnown(), nextUnknown()

getCurrentFieldKnown

public boolean getCurrentFieldKnown()
                             throws TipcException
Examines the current field and reports back if it is an actual value, or a field marked as having an 'unknown value'. Does not advance to the next field.

Returns:
true if the current field contains an actual value; false if the field is marked as having an 'unknown value'.
Throws:
TipcMsgEomException - if there is no field
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
appendUnknown(int), nextUnknown()

nextUnknown

public boolean nextUnknown()
                    throws TipcException
If the next field in the message is marked as an 'unknown value', this method will skip over the field and return true. If the field has a 'known value', the current field will not be advanced, and a TipcMsgBadFieldException will be thrown.

Returns:
true if the field has 'unknown value'
Throws:
TipcMsgBadFieldException - if the next field has a known value
TipcMsgEomException - if there is no next field.
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
appendUnknown(int), getCurrentFieldKnown()

nextObject

public java.lang.Object nextObject()
                            throws java.lang.Exception
Decodes the next field (which must be a binary field) as an arbitrary Java Object. Objects encoded into a binary field with the appendObject method are decoded with this method. Decoding objects carries the same restrictions as the standard Java serialization mechanism. Serialized objects must implement the Serializable interface.

Returns:
the object
Throws:
OptionalDataException - unexpected data was found
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - if the class definition cannot be loaded
TipcIOException - if the object cannot be read
TipcMsgBadFieldException - if the next field is not a binary field
TipcMsgUnknownFieldException - if the next field is marked unknown
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
appendObject(java.lang.Object)

public void setCurrent(int field_num)
                throws TipcException
Sets the current field of the message. The "current field" is a cursor indexing the fields in a message.

Parameters:
field_num - field number (0 indicates the first field)
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if field_num is negative or greater than the last index in the message.
TipcException

setDeliveryMode

public void setDeliveryMode(int delivery_mode)
                     throws TipcBadArgumentException
Sets the delivery mode property of the message. The delivery mode is one of: TipcDefs.DELIVERY_BEST_EFFORT, TipcDefs.DELIVERY_ORDERED, TipcDefs.DELIVERY_SOME, TipcDefs.DELIVERY_ALL.

Parameters:
delivery_mode - message delivery mode
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if delivery_mode is not one of the pre-defined values.
See Also:
TipcMt.setDeliveryMode(int), TipcMt.getDeliveryMode()

setDest

public void setDest(java.lang.String dest)
Sets the destination property of the message. The destination property is the subject this message is being published to. It has no meaning in peer-to-peer connections.

Parameters:
dest - message destinatation

setNumFields

public void setNumFields(int num_fields)
                  throws TipcBadArgumentException
Sets the number of fields in the message. If the number is smaller than the actual number of fields, the extra fields will be removed.

Parameters:
num_fields - number of fields
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if num_fields is larger than the actual number of fields.

setPriority

public void setPriority(short priority)
Sets the priority of the message.

Parameters:
priority - message priority
See Also:
TipcMt.setPriority(short), TipcMt.getPriority()

setSender

public void setSender(java.lang.String sender)
Sets the sender property of the message. The sender property identifies the sending client. By default, this is set to the unique subject of the client. For RTserver connections, this property is forced to the sender's unique subject, regardless of the setting of this property.

Parameters:
sender - message sender

setSeqNum

public void setSeqNum(int sn)
Sets the sequence number property of the message.

Parameters:
sn - sequence number

setType

public void setType(TipcMt mt)
             throws TipcBadArgumentException
Sets the message type of the message. Note that any default properties of the new message type do NOT affect this message's properties when this method is used.

Parameters:
mt - the message type
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if mt is not a valid message type.
See Also:
TipcMt

setUserProp

public void setUserProp(int user_prop)
Sets the user property of the message. The user property is any arbitrary value the user assigns.

Parameters:
user_prop - user property
See Also:
TipcMt.getUserProp(), TipcMt.setUserProp(int)

setCompression

public void setCompression(boolean compression)
Sets the compression property of the message. The compression property indicates whether the message data is to be compressed at the time it is sent. The message won't be uncompressed until a receiver of the message attempts to access any of the message's data fields. The compression used is governed by the ss.compression_name and ss.compression_args options.

Parameters:
compression - the compression property of the message
See Also:
getCompression(), TipcMt.getCompression(), TipcMt.setCompression(boolean)

setDeliveryTimeout

public void setDeliveryTimeout(double delivery_timeout)
                        throws TipcBadArgumentException
Sets the delivery timeout property of the message. The delivery timeout determines how long the client will wait for a GMD acknowledgement before deciding that a failure has occurred.

Parameters:
delivery_timeout - delivery timeout (in seconds)
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if delivery_timeout is negative.
See Also:
TipcMt.getDeliveryTimeout(), TipcMt.setDeliveryTimeout(double)

setLbMode

public void setLbMode(int lb_mode)
               throws TipcBadArgumentException
Sets the load balancing mode of the message. The load balancing mode is one of: TipcDefs.LB_NONE, TipcDefs.LB_ROUND_ROBIN, TipcDefs.LB_WEIGHTED, TipcDefs.LB_SORTED.

Parameters:
lb_mode - load balanacing mode
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if lb_mode is not one of the pre-defined types.
See Also:
TipcMt.getLbMode(), TipcMt.setLbMode(int)

print

public void print(java.io.PrintWriter out)
Prints the message. Prints the message in human readable form, showing the value of all user-settable fields as well as all data currently in the message.

Parameters:
out - The stream to print to.

Parameters:
out - The stream to print to.

print

public void print()
Prints the message to the SmartSockets "standard" output stream. Prints the message in human readable form, showing the value of all user-settable fields as well as all data currently in the message.

addNamedUnknown

public void addNamedUnknown(java.lang.String name,
                            int type)
                     throws TipcException
Appends a new named field of the specified type to the message, but marks the field as 'value unknown'. The constants required for the parameter, field_type, are specified in this module (TipcMsg) and can be recognized by their FT_* names.

Parameters:
name - the name to use
type - the type of field to append and mark as an 'unknown value'
Throws:
TipcAssertionException - if bad field type parameter is passed in
TipcAlreadyExistsException - if the named field already exists
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
appendUnknown(int)

addNamedObject

public void addNamedObject(java.lang.String name,
                           java.lang.Object obj)
                    throws TipcException
Appends an arbitrary Java Object to the message, with a name. The object will be encoded in a binary field, using the standard serialization mechanism. Therefore, the object passed to this method must implement the Serializable interface. Note that any objects to be serialized must not only themselves implemented Serializable, but all of the classes they extend must be Serializable.

This object will only be useful to receiving clients in Java. C clients will receive a binary field which may be forwarded to other Java clients.

Parameters:
name - the name to use
obj - the object to be appended
Throws:
TipcIOException - if the object serialization fails
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
appendObject(java.lang.Object)

                        throws TipcException

Returns:
the field data

TipcMsgBadFieldException - if the field has a known value

setNameCurrent

public void setNameCurrent(java.lang.String name)
                    throws TipcException
Sets the name of the current field. Note that appending a new field does not advance the current field index, so you must manually set the current field after appending a field to a message.

Parameters:
name - the name to set
Throws:
TipcMsgEomException - if there is no field at the current field index (the index is past the end of the message).
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
getNameCurrent(), setCurrent(int)

getNameCurrent

public java.lang.String getNameCurrent()
                                throws TipcException
Returns the name of the current field. Returns null if the current field is not named.

Throws:
TipcException - for any errors
See Also:
setNameCurrent(java.lang.String)

getNamedFieldKnown

public boolean getNamedFieldKnown(java.lang.String name)
                           throws TipcException
Examines the named field and reports back if it is an actual value, or a field marked as having an 'unknown value'. Does not advance to the next field.

Returns:
true if the named field contains an actual value; false if the field is marked as having an 'unknown value'.
Throws:
TipcMsgException - if there is no field by that name
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
addNamedUnknown(java.lang.String, int)

                   throws TipcException

updateNamedObject

public void updateNamedObject(java.lang.String name,
                              java.lang.Object obj)
                       throws TipcException
Updates a named arbitrary Java Object in the message. The object will be encoded in a binary field, using the standard serialization mechanism. Therefore, the object passed to this method must implement the Serializable interface. Note that any objects to be serialized must not only themselves implemented Serializable, but all of the classes they extend must be Serializable.

This object will only be useful to receiving clients in Java. C clients will receive a binary field which may be forwarded to other Java clients.

Parameters:
name - the name to use
obj - the object to be appended
Throws:
TipcIOException - if the object serialization fails
TipcMsgException - if there is no field by that name
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
appendObject(java.lang.Object), addNamedObject(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object)
